div.p: From William Potter to Charles Topp
F97/2162, unit 972, VPRS 3992/P inward registered correspondence, VA 475 Chief Secretary's Department, Public Record Office, Victoria.
In the ESTATE of the LATE BARON SIR FERDINAND VON MUELLER, K.C.M.G., LL.D., M.& Ph. D., F.R.S.

div.p:
On behalf of the Executors of the Late Baron Sir Ferdinand Von Mueller, K.C.M.G., Government Botanist of Victoria I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letters dated Jan 7 and Feb 13 189 7,
Letters not found. having reference to books in the library of the deceased Baron, said to be the property of the Government.

In reply permit me to say that we have already delivered to Mr Luehmann all books marked with the initials "G.P."
Government Property. I wonder which of the books w/o GP had been brought after the sale of the existing Library to the Govt in the 1860s, and how many of those were actually private. It will be necessary for someone sometime to check whether at MEL library there are , say, any 1870 /1880 publications with GP added. Is the list that they say Luehmann is supposed to have had an inventory of who owned what, I wonder?
together with other government property, and that every effort is now being made to get the government correspondence assorted ready for your department. As soon as that has been done, we will at once search for, and hand to Mr Luehmann, any other books belonging to the Government that may still be in the library, and also have a catalogue prepared of the books to be offered to you for purchase.

I may say that the delay and the worry has arisen through the disarrangement of the books and papers in a fruitless search for some important documents which the Baron stated were in Mr Luehmann's charge, but which that gentleman denies ever having had, and has failed to deliver up.

It is hardly necessary that I should assure you of the Executors' earnest desire to meet the wishes of your department in every way possible. A month will suffice for completing the work now in hand, and the books you require will then be sorted out.
On 23 March 1897 Topp minuted: 'I understand all the property will be handed over in a week, the […] is not to be given till this is done. Put with other papers'.

div.p: I have the honour to be
